headline: How Olubadan stool rotates between civil, military chieftaincy lines

headline: BREAKING: Ex-Osun military administrator, Anthony Obi dies
summarized_story:
The former military administrator of Osun State, Colonel Anthony Uzoma Obi (rtd) is dead.
Obi, who served as the military governor of Osun State between August 1996 and August 1998, died on Saturday, January 1, as announced by his family.
Osun State Governor, Gboyega Oyetola, in a condolence message, mourned the demise of the former military administrator.
“The death of Colonel Anthony Obi (rtd) is painful and a huge loss not only to his family but to the nation.

headline: Accident: Ortom warns NKST Synod against transporting members to conferences with trucks
summarized_story:
Pained by the series of unfortunate incidents that follow the use of lorries and trucks in conveying their members to conferences, the Benue State Governor, Samuel Ortom has warned the Synod of the NKST to desist from such acts forthwith.
This followed reported accident cases by congregants to this year’s conference at Atukpu, Taraku in Gwer East Local Government Area.
Governor Ortom gave the warning Sunday, January 2nd, 2022 while addressing the congregation at the ongoing MIM National Conference at NKST Atukpu, Gwer West Local Government Area of Benue State.
He called for more diligent planning where adequate transportation and other logistics will be made for such events.
Governor Ortom traced the fruits of dedicating Benue State to God with the selection of men of God becoming traditional rulers, stressing that by this alone, more traditional rulers have become active members in the Church.

headline: Bogoro crisis: Dass youths protest attack on emir
summarized_story:
Following Friday’s attack on the convoys of the Emirs of Bauchi and Dass on their way to Bogoro to attend the 21st memorial anniversary of Sayawa nation crusader, Baba Peter Gonto, youths from Dass on Saturday demonstrated to protest the ill-treatment of their Emir, Usman Bilyaminu Othman, by irate youths.
DAILY POST reports that violence erupted during the memorial anniversary in Bogoro, leading to the destruction of property worth millions of naira as well as burning of houses of some prominent individuals in the area.
The demonstrating youth blocked the ever-busy Dass-Tafawa Balewa highway, preventing people to go or come out from both Tafawa Balewa and Bogoro Local Government Areas to retaliate the attack on their Emir’s convoy.
DAILY POST learnt that vehicular movement was paralysed as a result of the demonstration, while the angry youth refused to listen to entreaties by prominent individuals from Dass, the headquarters of Dass LGA.
As tension rose high with the youth being adamant, the Emir, Alhaji Usman Bilyaminu Othman, had to intervene, as the traditional ruler went to meet the demonstrators to pacify them to allow peace to reign.

headline: Banditry: Matawalle, two northern govs meet Niger Republic President

According to the president, Niger Republic will continue to support Nigeria in its effort to find lasting peace especially from the menace of banditry and insurgency.
Recall that Matawalle made a similar visit last month where he donated four Hilux vans to the security operatives of Niger Republic to assist them in the patrol along the borders to fight the incursion of criminal elements into the country.

headline: How next Olubadan of Ibadan will emerge
summarized_story:

The Olubadan throne is open to all Ibadan indigenes able to climb the chieftaincy ladder.
- Advertisement -From Jagun, candidates climb 21 steps before emerging as the Olubadan on the Otun Olubadan line, while candidates climb 22 other steps on the Balogun line.
The promotion in the line of Otun Olubadan follows this pattern: From Jagun – Ajia – Bada – Aare Onibon – Gbonnka – Aare-Egbe Omo – Oota – Lagunna – Are-Ago – Ayingun – Asaju – Ikolaba – Aare-Alasa – Agba-Akin – Ekefa – Maye – Abese – Ekaarun Olubadan – Ekerin Olubadan – Ashipa Olubadan – Osi Olubadan – Otun Olubadan, before emerging as Olubadan.
There are indications that the Otun Olubadan of Ibadan land, Senator Lekan Balogun, may be next in line as the Olubadan of Ibadan.

headline: 2022 Budget: Buhari Will Not Hamper Implementation Despite Changes – Garba Shehu
summarized_story:

This is according to a statement issued by the Senior Special Assistant to the President, Garba Shehu, on Sunday.
President Buhari had on Friday morning signed the budget into law and expressed strong reservations on what he described as worrisome changes made by the National Assembly to the 2022 Executive Budget proposal.

headline: Gov. Ugwuanyi signs N186.64 billion 2022 budget into law
summarized_story:
Enugu state Governor, Ifeanyi Ugwuanyi has assented to the 2022 appropriation bill of 186,64 billion naira recently passed by the State House of Assembly.
Presenting the appropriation bill to Governor Ugwuanyi for assent, the Speaker of the State House of Assembly, Edward Ubosi disclosed that the budget proposal was a wonderful budget of international standard.
Ubosi explained that all the Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) appeared before the various committees to ensure they defended their budget estimates.
Assenting to the appropriation bill, Governor Ugwuanyi expressed gratitude to God and the members of the State House of Assembly for their commitment and dedication to legislative duties as well as the development of Enugu State.
He expressed confidence that the budget would be implemented faithfully for the people of the state to enjoy more dividends of democracy.

headline: Tinubu condoles with Gov Ganduje, Sharia Council over Sheikh Datti Ahmed's death -
summarized_story:
The All Progressives Congress National Leader, Asiwaju Bola Tinubu, has commiserated with Kano State Governor Abdullahi Ganduje and the Supreme Council for Sharia in Nigeria over the death of elder-statesman and president of the council, Dr. Datti Ahmed.
He said throughout his life, Dr. Ahmed symbolised and fought for justice, equity and fairness adding that his demise was a loss not only to the Muslim community in Nigeria but to all Nigerians.
“As a first generation medical doctor from Kano State, Dr. Ahmed dedicated his life to the service of humanity.
“The death of Dr. Ahmed is a great loss to the medical community in Nigeria and the comity of Islamic scholars.
“My condolences to his family, Kano State Governor Abdullahi Ganduje, the government and people of the state, Muslims across the country, and Nigerians as a whole.

headline: Auditor General indicts NASS over alleged misappropriation of N9.4b -
summarized_story:
The Office of the Auditor General for the Federation has indicted the management of the National Assembly and the National Assembly Service Commission for alleged unexplained expenditure amounting to N9.4 billion in the 2019 financial year.
The report said about N5.5 billion of such expenditure was credited to the House of Representatives in five different audit queries, N3.5 billion credited to the Senate in seven audit queries, while N307.6 million was credited to the National Assembly Service Commission in two audit queries.
The queries are contained in the Auditor General’s annual report on non-compliance and internal control weaknesses issues in Ministries, departments and agencies of the federal government for the year ended 31st December 2019.
The Report addressed to the Clerk to the National Assembly was signed by the Auditor General for the Federation, Adolphus Aghughu.
The report said N2.5 billion was granted to members of the House of Representatives as running costs between July and December 2019 without evidence to show what the funds were used for even as it was not retired.

headline: Somali President suspends PM Roble, accuses him of undermining legislative elections
summarized_story:
President of Somalia Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed stated Monday that he is suspending Prime Minister Mohamed Hussein Roble, widening the political schism between the country’s top officials.
According to a spokeswoman for President Mohamed, also known as Farmajo, the move was taken in response to an investigation into an illegal acquisition of public land involving Prime Minister Roble.
The prime minister accused Mohamed of obstructing parliamentary elections, prompting Roble’s suspension.
Earlier this year, the feuding leaders agreed to enable 101 delegates to choose members of parliament, who would then choose the future head of state.
Observers fear that the feud between Farmajo and Roble will divert attention away from the ongoing threat posed by the al Shabab insurgent group, which has fought the central government in an attempt to seize power and impose sharia law in Somalia, which has been wracked by chaos and conflict since the overthrow of former dictator Mohamed Siad Barre in 1991.

headline: Nigeria Should Focus on Increasing Revenue: Ayo Teriba
summarized_story:

headline: Israeli Jets Hit Militant Targets in Gaza After Rocket Fire
summarized_story:
Israel’s military said early Sunday it launched strikes against militant targets in the Gaza Strip, a day after rockets were fired from the Hamas-ruled territory.
Video filmed in Khan Younis, southern Gaza Strip, showed three huge explosions and fighter jets could be heard flying overhead.
The Israeli military said the attacks targeted a rocket manufacturing facility and a military post for Hamas.
It also blamed the militant Islamic group for any violence emanating from the territory it controls.
It was not clear whether the rockets were meant to hit Israel, but Gaza-based militant groups often test-fire missiles toward the sea.

headline: France to Cut Covid Isolation Time for Fully Vaccinated People
summarized_story:
France says it will reduce the isolation period for fully vaccinated people who test positive for COVID-19.
Health Minister Olivier Veran told the newspaper Le Journal du Dimanche on Sunday that fully vaccinated people will only have to isolate for seven days instead of 10, beginning on Monday.
But those who are not vaccinated and who test positive “will have to self-isolate for 10 days, with a possibility to come out of isolation after seven days under the same terms”, Veran said.
Other countries such as the United States also reduced this week the isolation period for COVID-19 to five days in a bid to prevent disruptions in industries for lack of staff.
It said the decision to reduce isolation periods was “aimed at ensuring the virus is controlled while maintaining socioeconomic life”.
